bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 24, 1923

div1.p: Hanson informs Carter that he has settled in Jacksonville, Florida and has started his own practice. He discusses an alleged case of Weil's Disease in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 24, 1923
div1.p:
I have been thinking of writing you ever since we
arrived but, with the business of getting settled, looking for and office
and the effort to take care of some of thewrok which the local men want me
to do it has not seemed that the day had hours enough for what was to be
done. Now we are almost settled in our house, which promises to be both
comfortable and with sufficient “lujo”, in fact we have a place where we
can and would be delighted to entertain both Dr. Carter and his charming
daughter Laura, at any time which they see fit to notify us that they
are coming. The weather is fine, the evenings cool enough to make one
revel in the burning of pitchy pine knots in the fireplace, the only
drawback to the latter procedure is that it is so demoralizing to work,
one simply wants to sit lazily by gazing and dreaming.

The present indications for the work are most too good to be
true. If it keeps up I shall have more work than I can take care of. The
Profession have been most courteous, and the daily papers has come out
with the usual squib of what a h--- of a fellow I am and the miracles (?)
accomplished. Seriously I can not complain of the reception to my “home
coming” It has been five years and eight months from the time I left for
my army service until I returned to take up residence again, and it has
actually seemed like coming home.

I believe the work here can be made a real success. The doctors
claim that it will only be limited by the amount of work I want to do. They
say they have had no one in whom they have had full confidence since I left
in 1917.

Now to come to something important. I have just received a letter
from Dr. Rose with enclosures of copies of report on the Weil's disease in
Guayaquil. I do not like the looks of things. I enclose the copy of my letter
to Dr. Rose. I di not make an extra copy so will ask that you return this, as
I have sort of gotten a habit of keeping copies of letters to him. As I said
to Dr. Rose I wish that you and I could make a survey of that coast together.
It ought to be done as the situation can yet be saved, but the delay should
not be too long. I believe that we have a more vital interest in that coast
so far as the yellow fever situation is concerned than any one else, and it
is certainly worth while to the I.H.B. to have this thing done; but who is to
do it? In a case of this kind unless you be one of the party I shall not feel
altogather satisfied with the final report. Four case out of seven dying on
or before the sixth day is not very characteristic of Weil's Disease, but is
quite paralell to what we saw in Peru, No doubt you have seen the report which
Dr. Coello sent to the Surgeon General, U.S.PH.S.

I have nothing new to write, do not seem to be able to get my mind
of this report.

Our trip down was pleasant all the way, and the children as usual
seemed to improve in health as we toured. We had a bit of rough road in South
Carolina, about two miles of bad road near Oxford, N.C. and some small stretches
betweenxxxxxxxx Savannah and Jacksonville, but nothing which was really diffi-
cult to pass. We stayed in Savannah from Sunday to Wednesday, while there I
called on your friend Dr. “Bill” Brunner, who like the rest of us is a great
admirer of yours.
With the best of good wishes for you and Laura,
